ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: New insight into networks and infrastructures that was very eye-opening for a STEM major
New perspectives on globalization and interconnected networks of people and space, as well as the flow of information and technnology.
I gained a really broad understanding of infrastructure networks, and i learned a lot of vocabulary that relates to these topics. (There is a lot of jargon to learn!)
I learned about the architecture, infrastructure, and technical side of global affairs. Very interesting perspective and historical approach to GLBL.
None
Learnt about aesthetics, infrastructure, architecture, networks  was nice to compile different topics under one broader theme
I learned about the ways location and space can create advantage/disadvantage(s). It really opened my eyes to a new way of thinking about the world.
I learned several topics about the globalization of the world including ways that the world is interconnected by means of transportation the economy and culture.
I was able to gain an enhanced understanding of how infrastructures and the structure of spaces affects various aspects of the political, economic, and social spheres.
The class is thoroughly engaging. Prof Easterling presents fascinating info on globalization, its merits, and dismerits
None

This is one of those Yale courses that teaches you a new way of thinking and really changes the way you see the world. The lectures take you on a journey through the connections, relationships, and loops of people, organizations, and countries in history, studying infrastructure, NGO's, and pretty much every other part of our lives that you may have taken for granted and deconstructs it in a multi-disciplinary perspective.

As an overarching theme, I learned about all the hidden organizations, systems and design principles that literally, physically shape our world. I feel like the biggest skills I developed were reading academic papers and also thinking about issues in a much less disciplinary way.
This class opened my eyes to the ways in which narratives of capital and infrastructure shape every part of our existence as global citizens.
I learned a lot about the forces that come together to make globalization happen, and all the complications/tiny details involved in the process.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The content itself is so interesting and relevant, the main weakness is the lack of clarity and expectations in assignments (of which there are only project milestones towards the final project). The course is cross listed so nearly everyone at Yale can take it, which is great, but it feels more geared toward grad students and is pretty ambiguous to an undergrad

Topics were rather large and abstract and, although there was potential, did not relate back to current events/moments. It was good for getting a general idea of space in an urban context as well as how certain themes and ideas are a global occurence.
The course is really interesting, but sometimes I felt that it was trying to cover TOO much in one semester. Perhaps it could be streamlined a bit.

Lectures were super interesting, and we covered a wide array of topics which was absolutely great. Of course, the virtual component made discussion section difficult, but overall the course was really good. Potentially would have been nice to have *more assignments, to increase course engagement and incentivize understanding of materials.

Strengths:
- Understanding teaching team
- Variety of topics

Weaknesses:
- Basically zero feedback on student work prior to final project submission
- Poor selection of weekly readings
- ???? don't know what I learned besides a few niche facts here and there
Very weak course lack of connections between the materials taught
Enjoyed the pecha kucha! But I wish the class had more structure in terms of content
More interaction with the class. I know it was difficult being online, but even in section our TA was not very engaging at all and made it very boring.
No weaknesses! The lectures were well organized, the TFs were extremely helpful, and the variety of topics discussed made the class even more interesting

weaknesses: the zoom format was a little less engaging than in person but that cant be helped! Very greatful for all the effort Prof Easterling put into creating immersive, multimedia slides and lectures though!!!
Lectures had no relevance, content was not graded at all

I think the strength of the course is the lecture style. A lot of people complain about dry lectures that you can read off the lecture notes but this is probably the first lecture class I've taken where traditional lecture notes would really not do you much good. It's all about the approaches you take to a particular issue, and the interesting ideas and claims that Prof. Easterling makes along the way that you want to pay attention to. The one improvement I would make is that Prof. Easterling has slides with numbers on them to mark "interplays" and it would be nice to have an updated powerpoint with each one to better track the themes throughout the course.

The lectures were phenomenal and the readings were incredibly interesting. For some reason, however, engagement of others in discussion section and lecture was incredibly weak. Maybe there need to be stronger incentives to get people to read and participate? Also, we never get a single grade in this course until the very end -- that accords well with the culture and fit but makes it very unpredictable and feel less like an academic class which demands academic engagement.

I loved the TedTalk-esque format, and found the lectures really engaging and interesting. The only negative was that some of the readings were quite dry and difficult to process--some more modern selections/news articles would've been more appealing. I also would've enjoyed hearing more about Keller's own work.
The lectures were very engaging!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recording the lectures was a great idea for reviewing content; my section had a forum for posting short reading responses/questions which was good for engaging in virtual space

The virtual lecture and discussion section were great! I appreciated that attendance was suggested, but that lectures were recorded so that we could review material later on if we needed, or if we couldn't attend a given lecture for whatever reason.
All of them
I enjoyed lectures and discussion sections were really interactive too!

I feel like the best aspect that this class did was making our final project a group oriented project because it made it possible to meet people in the class he might have not met online if it wasnt for this project.
The fact that both Professor Easterling and the TFs were very understanding to students' needs made navigating the class during the pandemic so much easier
Our TF's sections used "miro board" and this was really engaging for online discussion and connection of ideas in a visual learning way. it felt more tactile!
Discussion sections were helpful to discuss material
It was really convenient that the lectures were recorded. I wish they had made people turn their cameras on in section because it was weird when people left the off.
If more people had kept their cameras on, I think there would've been better discussion.

We used Miro boards for discussion sections, and I think that kind of took away the discussion part, since now people were replying to each other on the boards and during the section it was just like reading from the board.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to engage yourself in interesting material, have important discussions, and are fine with ambiguity about your final grade.
Only if they're interested in the topics at hand
Yes, I recommend this to anyone interested in urban planning, infrastructure, telecommunications, trade, and issues of globalization.
Yes! A great, low-stress course for GLBL or ARCH majors. Honestly just a good time.

Depends on your goal. If you just want to get a humanities credit without writing a bunch of essays, I would recommend the course. If you are looking for a worthwhile learning experience, choose a different course.
No
Yes!!
It's quite easy in terms of workload and readings etc. but wouldn't say it's super engaging

Yes, I'd recommend this course to a student looking for something interesting but not too time-intensive. Most of the course is a super light workload with a few readings a week to prepare for section (sometimes kind of long) and then most of the work concentrated on a final project. The TAs are pretty cool and focused on facilitating genuine discussion during sections, which was definitely appreciated.
Unless you are in architecture major or in urbanism major do not take this class. It was very specific to those majors and even as someone who is in urban studies major I found it quite boring.
Yes I would! It gives you a very holistic perspective of how the world works!

Yes! Prof. Easterling is fantastic and you'll learn a lot. Show up for the first lecture, see if it sparks anything for you and if so, take it!! Its not very hard but you learn so much about the world and the strange networks of power, technology, economy, and culture that drive it.
No. Lectures had no relevance to the graded assignments, no feedback at all throughout the semester either.
Yes, I would highly recommend this to any Yale student regardless of major. It's listed as an architecture course but it really is so much more and there is something for everybody to learn from.
Absolutely; it exposes you to a wide range of thought in "disciplines" from sociology to philosophy to urbanism and realize that there are vital global issues that no one is talking about.
yes--for people both with and without prior exposure to this field of study alike. A reasonable workload that piques your interest in a myriad of ways.
Yes, you learn a lot about the world.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Additional virtual in-person weekly discussion section
Live virtual lecture twice a week and virtual seminar-style discussion section once a week
lectures were also recorded for asynchronous viewing
Live/recorded lecture, weekly discussion section (virtual)
Live virtual lecture with a live virtual discussion section.
live virtual sections
Virtual lecture + virtual discussion sections
Live virtual discussion sections weekly
weekly virtual discussion
None
N/A
+zoom section meetings
Lectures with discussion sections
In addition to the lectures twice a week, there was a weekly discussion section led by a grad student.
live virtual lecture w/ discussion section
The lectures were also recorded.
